awd_abstract_narration:
The 2016 Graduate Student Combinatorics Conference will be held April 1-3, 2016 at Clemson University, Clemson, SC. The main purpose of this conference is to bring together graduate students in combinatorics in order to educate participants about the many areas of combinatorics, provide a venue for sharing current research topics and open questions, have participants meet fellow graduate students from across the country, and provide an opportunity for students to collaborate on current research problems. The conference will feature two plenary one-hour speakers and a number of twenty-minutes contributed talks by graduate students. This will be the 12th annual conference in this series which was started in 2005 at the University of Minnesota. The conference will be publicized via email and information will be posted on a conference website. 

The conference provides an opportunity for graduate students to learn about the current research in all areas of combinatorics, including algebraic and enumerative combinatorics, graph theory, design theory, and coding theory. The conference is designed specifically for graduate students and it is organized essentially by the graduate students themselves. Combinatorics faculty from Clemson and the invited speakers will act as mentors for the graduate students throughout the process. The conference promotes recent advances in research and exposition of students' research in a supportive environment.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The 12th annual Graduate Student Combinatorics Conference (GSCC) was held at Clemson University in Clemson, SC from April 1-3, 2016.

GSCC 2016 was organized by a group of 6 graduate students from Clemson University. They planned the event, recruited two keynote speakers, secured additional $3000 support from Clemson University, advertised the conference,  maintained a conference website, planned the budget, and managed all the logistics for the meeting. This left them with a great experience in planning and executing conferences. 

The conference was attended by 55 graduate students from 17 states and 3 countries (USA, Canada, China).  It was a lively event in which the graduate students had an opportunity to report on their research as well as interact with their peers; events like this greatly help junior researchers in forming support networks and future collaborations. 

The conference began Friday afternoon with a departmental colloquium titled "Properties and applications of vanishing ideals of points over finite fields" by Elena Dimitrova (Associate Professor, Clemson). After that was the Clemson University Math Club, Clemson undergraduate Corrin George spoke about her research. Saturday morning consisted of three consecutive size-three parallel sessions where the graduate students gave 20-minute talks. After lunch was a keynote address titled "Partitions, polytopes, and Catalan combinatorics", by Jon McCammond (Professor, UC Santa Barbara). This was followed by three more parallel sessions, and another keynote address titled "Schur-positive grid classes" by Sergi Elizalde (Associate Professor, Dartmouth). Rather than have a banquet or go out to separate resaurants in small groups, there was a pizza party Saturday night on campus, to encourage maximum networking and social interaction among the attendees. Sunday morning consisted of five more parallel sessions of size-three for graduate student talks. 

Details from the conference can be found at: https://sites.google.com/site/gscccu16/.


Last Modified: 05/31/2017
Modified by: Svetlana Poznanovikj
